Day Trip Planner: Jasper, TN

    #day-trips
Original Author: Viki Vaillancourt - Contributing Writer
Last Updated: 08/05/2024
Start your day with local coffee
Jasper, Tennessee might not be the first town that pops into your head when you consider a day trip but this small Marion County hidden gem has more to offer than meets the eye as far as getting away from it all. Just up the road from beautiful Chattanooga, Jasper has a nature lover's itch that can only be scratched by combining beauty with village charm and lazing in this slice of history is lazy days perfection juice for me. Along this thoughtfully planned road trip, you'll begin your morning with a cup of coffee from the locals whose daily routine takes them down backroad paths surrounded by trails and ancient grounds punctuated only by refreshing flavors unique to town. Although Jasper might be tiny, its spot near some of Tennessee's most majestic natural wonders helps this small town stand out as a place worth stopping. From the outdoorsman to the foodie, those looking for a quiet getaway: Jasper offers up 24 hours of charming finds that truly reflect small town Tennessee. Grab your sense of exploration and get ready for a day where each stop will show something unique, truly allowing you to remember this experience in Jasper.

1.  Breakfast at Lookout Valley Coffee Shop

Location: 1401 New Home Rd, Jasper, TN 37347
Time: 8:00 AM - 9:00 AM
About: Lookout Valley Coffee Shop is a neighborhood-kinda-place where you can have the coziest beginning to your day. However, as there is only a scarce amount of information available on the website concerning its whereabouts and operational hours hence it would be wise to check where exactly this panda cafe in Tokyo (shinjuku) really is before making your way down. And if the place isn´t open, you can get a fast breakfast option for early hours in some diners or even the usual fast-food places. Chances are, the ambiance is informal and homey (in that small-town coffeehouse sort of way).
Crowds: It is likely that being a lesser-known shop, the crowds will be small. Perfect for a quiet start.

2.  A Morning Hike at Sewanee Natural Bridge

Location: Natural Bridge Rd, Sewanee, TN 37375
Time: 9:30 AM - 11:00 AM
Of note: The Sewanee Natural Bridge is a natural sandstone arch that makes for an easy and beautiful hike. This slice of the University of the South Domain offers expansive views and trails into pristine woods. The bridge itself is only a short gap in the rocks but like all of nature it offers excellent photo opportunities. It is usually well-kept by the college.
Hours of Operation: The area is typically open during daylight hours.
Crowds: Early mornings are best to visit with the least amount of people, although it is not too bad anyways.
Pro tips: The trail is uneven, so make sure to wear sturdy shoes. Do plan before you go, since it is easy to slip when the track gets wet. For the best photographs of nature, make sure to pack your camera.
A local deli in black and white

3.  Lunch at The Dutch Maid Bakery & Café

Location: 109 Main St, Tracy City, TN 37387
Time: 12:00 PM - 1:00 PM
About: Dutch Maid Bakery & Cafe is Tennessee's Oldest Family Owned Bakery serving delicious, freshly baked goods along with amazing sandwiches and home cooked meals. Certainly, with a history that dates back to 1902 the bakery is both rewarding in flavor as it also offers up some local 'color.' On a daily basis, favorites such as their Reuben sandwich; quiches made from scratch and iconic sugar cookies. It has a warm, cozy atmosphere that represents the quaintness of anything you could grab at a small-town bakery.
Hours of Operation: Monday to Saturday from 6 am to 4 pm; Sunday Closed
Crowds: It gets super crowded during lunch, especially on weekends so it's best to go early. It is well-known all over for local and visitors both.
The Dutch Maid Bakery & Café

4.  Afternoon at Grundy Lakes State Park

Location: 587 Lakes Rd, Tracy City, TN 37387
Time: 1:30 PM - 3:30 PM
Description: Grundy Lakes State Park is part of the South Cumberland State Park and includes a handful of tiny lakes, some old coke ovens to explore, hiking trails along with scattered throughout. In addition to being an area which is set up for public relaxation, the park is also a place of knowledge where visitors can learn about industrial history. The trails are mostly moderate so that they can be traversed by most visitors. The park provides a mild workout and nature break in-between from the heavy lunch meal.
Top tip: if you fancy lounging around the lakes, bring a picnic blanket. The park can be hot in the afternoon so we advise sunblock and water. During the week it is usually less noisy.
Crowds: The park is generally quiet, especially during the week. Beautiful spots to chill out and escape the city chaos.

5.  Dinner at Stevarino's Italian Eatery and Pub

Location: 238 S Cedar Ave, South Pittsburg, TN 37380
Time: 6:00 PM - 7:30 PM
Editor's Note: Stevarino's Italian Eatery and Pub offers fully-Italian fair with a commitment to fresh ingredients, big portions. Set inside a historic family-owned building in South Pittsburg, this spot has that friendly neighborhood feel and serves all the favorites you crave: lasagna, calzones and oodles of hand-tossed pizzas. Guests traveling with pets can also enjoy a dog-friendly patio at the bistro. Private Lounge is particularly noteworthy for its local craft beers and handcrafted cocktails.
Hours: Mon-Sat 11am-9pm, Sunday Closed
Crowds: It gets crowded on weekends, so reservations are suggested. Even on busier nights the staff are friendly and more than willing to oblige.
Stevarino's Italian Eatery and Pub
Enjoy An Evening Stroll By The River

6.  Evening at Riverwalk Park

Location: Near the intersection of Betsy Pack Dr and 2nd St, Jasper, TN 37347
Time: 8:00 PM - 9:00 PM
About: Riverwalk Park Take a leisurely evening walk through the trails of RiverwalPark. Situated on the banks of the Tennessee River, Pickwick State Park is a quiet spot to rest up after chasing adrenaline highs all day. There are some wonderful sunsets views over the park's pathways along with a very well kept river. The place is generally quite in the evening and you can sit back here without anything to worry about outside. There are some benches on the walk where you can sit and enjoy the view; this is a popular walking spot for locals.
Tips: Sunsets are the best for scenic views! And if the weather is turning chilly, pack a cover up – it can get downright cold at night.
Crowds:The park generally gets a lot quieter in the evenings, allowing you to end your hectic day on a more peaceful note.

Jasper is much more than an exit off a highway it's both a place to dine and explore other small towns in Southeast Tennessee. Our itinerary is packed with fresh morning air on scenic trek, a hearty lunch ofzens from the famed Teascone bakery to peaceful evening by theriver. Whether you want to be off gallivanting or just take it easy, Jasper offers a perfectly scheduled day for all agendas. You will see as you explore that Jasper is just easy, and a down to Earth type of townThis place makes home feel warm

When you do go out, make sure to double-check on the hours and accessibility of your local spots before heading over—especially since some smaller venues may have reduced hours or limited access. Detailed advance planning ensures a seamless day that leaves you plenty of time to savor all this town has to offer. The natural beauty that envelops it, the small-town flavors that define it -- a Jasper day trip is so soothingly straightforward. By now, you might have noticed that Kitchen Without Borders is a bit of an escapist project for me—a sanctuary where the tempo slows down and the emphasis changes — from cooking to living in each moment: “Om nom,” be it savoring something tasty or dining al fresco among kindred company. By the time you get home, it will have been a day in Tennessee that was truly unforgettable.
